params.text: Chants and songs: Enslaved people were not allowed to write, and one way they passed down accounts of their lived realities was through chants and songs. These reveal how the enslaved felt about their lives and how they held onto their humanity. There are also songs of mourning and survival strategies.

Archival sources, although not written by enslaved, make references to them. An enslaved person who led an uprising in Curacao (Tula) is quoted in reports written by a Dutch priest, Father Jacobus Schinck, who was asked to convince him to surrender. The blue beads of St Eustatius in the Caribbean (Lohkay): Dr Felicia Fricke researches the lives of those enslaved in the Dutch Caribbean through combining the approaches of archaeology, osteology and oral history. Archaeological finds such as these beads in St Eustatius can be understood through interviewing the people currently living in the island. These beads were used as currency for people in slavery. When slavery was abolished in 1863, the beads were thrown into the sea. Until now, they make it to the surface and are worn as a symbol of freedom. Studying bone fragments (osteology) could also reveal the living conditions or causes of death for the enslaved.
